summary: This document is a chain of emails from June-July 2020 and 2019 between a U.S. Attorney's Office prosecutor and American Express Global Security personnel regarding the transmission of subpoenaed financial records related to Jeffrey Epstein. The correspondence details technical issues with secure document transfer and coordination to obtain a specific American Express account's statements.

persons.name: Yui Chow
persons.context: Mentioned as the sender of documents from the American Express office to the prosecutor.

events.title: Subpoena for Epstein Amex Account
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney informs American Express contacts of an impending narrow subpoena for one particular American Express account for one customer (Epstein) for a short period, requesting account statements.

events.title: Document Transfer Coordination
events.description: A series of emails between a prosecutor and American Express security personnel coordinating the secure transfer of subpoenaed documents related to Epstein, involving multiple attempts due to technical access issues.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively subpoenaing American Express for financial records related to Jeffrey Epstein as of June 2020.
The subpoena was described as narrow, targeting one specific American Express account for one customer (Epstein) for a short period, primarily seeking account statements.
American Express Global Security and its Financial Intelligence Unit were the points of contact for the Justice Department regarding these financial records.
The correspondence reveals operational challenges in transferring sensitive, encrypted documents between law enforcement and financial institutions during the investigation.
The document chain shows ongoing investigative activity related to Epstein's finances approximately a year after his arrest and death.
